(2015–present) | subsid = [[List of mergers and acquisitions by Alphabet|List of subsidiaries]] | footnotes = {{cite web|url=http://investor.google.com/proxy.html|title=Google Inc. Annual Reports |date=July 28, 2014|publisher=Google Inc.|accessdate=August 29, 2014}} | homepage = {{URL|https://www.google.com}} | foundation = {{start date and age|1998|09|4}}
[[Menlo Park, California]]{{cite web|title=Company|url=https://www.google.com/intl/en/about/company/|publisher=Google|accessdate=January 16, 2015}}{{cite web|first=Thomas |last=Claburn |title=Google Founded By Sergey Brin, Larry Page... And Hubert Chang?!? |url=http://www.informationweek.com/news/internet/google/210603678 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628231125/http://www.informationweek.com/news/internet/google/210603678 |website=[[InformationWeek]] |publisher=[[UBM plc]] |date=September 24, 2008 |archivedate=June 28, 2011 |accessdate=January 22, 2017 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} | founders = {{plainlist| * [[Larry Page]] * [[Sergey Brin]] }} | location_city = [[Googleplex]], [[Mountain View, California|Mountain View]], [[California]] | location_country = U.S.{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/about/jobs/locations/ |title=Locations — Google Jobs |publisher=Google.com |accessdate=September 27, 2013}} }} '''Google''' is an American [[multinational corporation|multinational]] [[technology company]] specializing in [[Internet]]-related services and products. These include [[online advertising]] technologies, [[Web search engine|search]], [[cloud computing]], [[software]], and [[Computer hardware|hardware]]. Google was founded in 1996 by [[Larry Page]] and [[Sergey Brin]] while they were [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] students at [[Stanford University]], in California. Together, they own about 14 percent of its shares and control 56 percent of the stockholder voting power through [[supervoting stock]]. They incorporated Google as a privately held company on September 4, 1998. An [[initial public offering]] (IPO) took place on August 19, 2004, and Google moved to its new headquarters in [[Mountain View, California]], nicknamed the [[Googleplex]].{{cite web |url=https://www.google.com/about/company/history/#2004 |title=Google history in depth|website=Google.com}} In August 2015, Google announced plans to reorganize its various interests as a [[Conglomerate (company)|conglomerate]] called [[Alphabet Inc.]] Google, Alphabet's leading subsidiary, will continue to be the umbrella company for Alphabet's Internet interests. Upon completion of the restructure, [[Sundar Pichai]] became [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of Google, replacing [[Larry Page]], who became CEO of Alphabet. Rapid growth since incorporation has triggered a chain of products, [[Mergers and acquisitions|acquisitions]], and partnerships beyond [[Google Search|Google's core search engine]] ([[Google Search]]). It offers services designed for work and productivity ([[Google Docs, Sheets and Slides]]), [[Webmail|email]] ([[Gmail]]/[[Inbox by Gmail|Inbox]]), scheduling and time management ([[Google Calendar]]), [[file hosting service|cloud storage]] ([[Google Drive]]), [[social networking service|social networking]] ([[Google+]]), instant messaging and video chat ([[Google Allo]]/[[Google Duo|Duo]]/[[Google Hangouts|Hangouts]]), language translation ([[Google Translate]]), mapping and turn-by-turn navigation ([[Google Maps]]), video sharing ([[YouTube]]), notetaking ([[Google Keep]]), and photo organizing and [[Image editing|editing]] ([[Google Photos]]). The company leads the development of the [[Android (operating system)|Android]] mobile [[operating system]], the [[Google Chrome]] web browser, and [[Chrome OS]], a lightweight operating system based on the Chrome browser. Google has moved increasingly into hardware; from 2010 to 2015, it partnered with major electronics manufacturers in the production of its [[Google Nexus|Nexus]] devices,{{cite news|title=It's Official: Google Is Now a Hardware Company|url=http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2012-05-22/its-official-google-is-now-a-hardware-company|accessdate=September 4, 2012|newspaper=Bloomberg Businessweek|date=May 22, 2012|author= Stone, Brad|author2= Burrows, Peter}} and in October 2016, it launched multiple hardware products (the [[Pixel (smartphone)|Google Pixel]] smartphone, [[Google Home|Home]], [[Google Wifi|Wifi]], and [[Google Daydream|Daydream View]]). The new hardware chief, Rick Osterloh, stated: "a lot of the innovation that we want to do now ends up requiring controlling the end-to-end user experience". Google has also experimented with becoming an Internet network operator. In February 2010, it announced [[Google Fiber]], a fiber-optic infrastructure that was installed in [[Kansas City, Kansas|Kansas City]]; in April 2015, it launched [[Project Fi]], combining Wi-Fi and cellular networks from different providers in an effort to create a seamless and fast wireless Internet experience; and in 2016, the company launched the Google Station initiative to make public "high-quality, secure, easily accessible Wi-Fi" around the world, which had already been deployed in [[India]]. An August 2011 report estimated that Google had almost one million servers in [[data center]]s around the world. It processed over one billion search requests per day in 2009, and about 20 [[petabyte]]s of data each day in 2008. [[Alexa Internet|Alexa]], a company that monitors commercial web traffic, lists Google.com as the most visited website in the world. Several other Google services also figure in the top 100 most visited websites, including [[YouTube]] and [[Blogger]]. Google has been the second most valuable brand in the world for 4 consecutive years, and was valued in 2016 at $133 billion. Google's [[mission statement]], from the outset, was "to organize the world's information and make it universally accessible and useful," and its unofficial slogan was "[[Don't be evil]]".{{cite web |url=https://www.google.com/corporate/ |title=Google Corporate Information |website=Google, Inc. |accessdate=February 14, 2010}}{{cite web |url=https://abc.xyz/investor/other/google-code-of-conduct.html |title=Google Code of Conduct |date=April 11, 2012 |website=Google, Inc. |accessdate=April 9, 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://blogoscoped.com/archive/2007-07-16-n55.html |title=Paul Buchheit on Gmail, AdSense and More |first=Philip|last=Lenssen |date=July 16, 2007 |website=Google Blogoscoped |accessdate=February 14, 2010}} In October 2015, the motto was replaced in the Alphabet corporate code of conduct by the phrase: "Do the right thing".{{cite web|title=Digital Equipment Corporation (1957-1998) Motto - Do the right thing|url=http://aknextphase.com/do-the-right-thing/|accessdate=14 July 2016|website=aknextphase.com}} Google's commitment to such robust idealism has been increasingly called into doubt due to a number of the firm's actions and behaviours which appear to contradict this.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/oct/25/evil-facebook-google-beheading-email-abuse|title=Who's more evil – Facebook or Google?|date=2013-10-25|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-08-28}}{{cite web |first=Roxane |last=Gay |title=The Blog That Disappeared |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/30/opinion/sunday/the-blog-that-disappeared.html |website=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 29, 2016 |accessdate=March 9, 2017}} ==History== {{Main article|History of Google}} [[File:Google1998.png|thumb|left|250px|Google's original homepage had a simple design because the company founders were inexperienced in [[HTML]], the [[markup language]] used for designing web pages.{{cite web|url=http://alan.blog-city.com/an_evening_with_googles_marissa_mayer.htm |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/61rJXKAeq?url=http://alan.blog-city.com/an_evening_with_googles_marissa_mayer.htm |archivedate=September 21, 2011 |title=An evening with Google's Marissa Mayer |last=Williamson |first=Alan |website=Alan Williamson |date=January 12, 2005 |accessdate=July 5, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}|alt=Google's homepage in 1998]] Google began in January 1996 as a research project by [[Larry Page]] and [[Sergey Brin]] when they were both PhD students at [[Stanford University]] in [[Stanford, California]].{{cite web |url=https://www.google.com/intl/en/corporate/history.html |title=Google Milestones |website=Google, Inc. |accessdate=September 28, 2010}} While conventional search engines ranked results by counting how many times the search terms appeared on the page, the two theorized about a better system that analyzed the relationships among websites.{{cite web |url=http://ilpubs.stanford.edu:8090/422/ |title=The PageRank Citation Ranking: Bringing Order to the Web |last1=Page |first1=Lawrence |last2=Brin |first2=Sergey |last3=Motwani |first3=Rajeev |last4=Winograd |first4=Terry |date=November 11, 1999 |website=Stanford University |accessdate=February 15, 2010}} They called this new technology [[PageRank]]; it determined a website's [[Relevance (information retrieval)|relevance]] by the number of pages, and the importance of those pages, that linked back to the original site.{{cite web |url=https://www.google.com/corporate/tech.html |title=Technology Overview |website=Google, Inc. |accessdate=February 15, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www-diglib.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/WP/get/SIDL-WP-1997-0072?1 |title=PageRank: Bringing Order to the Web |last=Page |first=Larry |website=Stanford Digital Library Project |date=August 18, 1997 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020506051802/https:/// |archivedate=May 6, 2002 |accessdate=November 27, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} Page and Brin originally nicknamed their new search engine "BackRub", because the system checked backlinks to estimate the importance of a site.{{Cite news |title=The Birth of Google |first=John |last=Battelle |newspaper=Wired |date=August 2005 |url=https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/13.08/battelle.html?tw=wn_tophead_4 |accessdate=October 12, 2010}}{{cite web|last1=Trex|first1=Ethan|title=9 People, Places & Things That Changed Their Names|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/20890/9-people-places-things-changed-their-names|website=Mental Floss|accessdate=August 4, 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://huron.stanford.edu |title=Backrub search engine at Stanford University |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19961224105215/http://huron.stanford.edu/ |archivedate=December 24, 1996 |accessdate=March 12, 2011}} Eventually, they changed the name to Google, originating from a misspelling of the word "[[googol]]",{{cite web|url=http://graphics.stanford.edu/~dk/google_name_origin.html |title=Origin of the name "Google" |last=Koller |first=David |date=January 2004 |website=Stanford University |accessdate=July 4, 2012 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/68ubHzYs7?url=http://graphics.stanford.edu/~dk/google_name_origin.html |archivedate=July 4, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}{{Cite news |url=http://www.stanforddaily.com/2003/02/12/from-googol-to-google |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100327141327/http://www.stanforddaily.com/2003/02/12/from-googol-to-google |archivedate=March 27, 2010 |title=From Googol to Google |last=Hanley |first=Rachael |date=February 12, 2003 |newspaper=The Stanford Daily |publisher=Stanford University |accessdate=February 15, 2010}} the number 1 followed by 100 zeros, which was picked to signify that the search engine was intended to provide large quantities of information.{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/company.html |title=Google! Beta website |website=Google, Inc. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990221202430/https:/// |archivedate=February 21, 1999 |accessdate=October 12, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} Originally, Google ran under Stanford University's website, with the domains ''google.stanford.edu'' and ''z.stanford.edu''.{{cite web |url=http://google.stanford.edu |title=Google! Search Engine |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19981111183552/http://google.stanford.edu/ |website=Stanford University |archivedate=November 11, 1998 |accessdate=October 12, 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://z.stanford.edu/ |title=Google! Search Engine |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19981201235013/http://z.stanford.edu/ |website=Stanford University |archivedate=December 1, 1998 |accessdate=August 14, 2012}} The domain name for Google was registered on September 15, 1997,{{cite web|url=http://whois.domaintools.com/google.com|title=Google.com WHOIS, DNS, & Domain Info - DomainTools|website=[[WHOIS]]|date= |accessdate=2016-07-11}} and the company was incorporated on September 4, 1998. It was based in the garage of a friend ([[Susan Wojcicki]]) in [[Menlo Park, California]]. [[Craig Silverstein]], a fellow PhD student at Stanford, was hired as the first employee.{{cite web|url=http://www-cs-students.stanford.edu/~csilvers/ |title=Craig Silverstein's website |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19991002122809/https:/// |archivedate=October 2, 1999 |website=Stanford University |accessdate=October 12, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}{{Cite news |last=Kopytoff |first=Verne |url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2008-09-07/news/17161124_1_larry-page-google-search-engine |title=Craig Silverstein grew a decade with Google |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |publisher=Hearst Communications, Inc. |date=September 7, 2008 |accessdate=October 12, 2010}} ===Financing, 1998 and initial public offering, 2004=== [[File:Google’s First Production Server.jpg|upright|thumb|Google's first production server. Google's production servers continue to be built with inexpensive hardware.{{cite web |url=http://www.computerhistory.org/collections/accession/102662167 |title=Google Server Assembly |website=Computer History Museum |accessdate=July 4, 2010}}|alt=Google's first servers, showing lots of exposed wiring and circuit boards]] The first funding for Google was an August 1998 contribution of $100,000 from [[Andy Bechtolsheim]], co-founder of [[Sun Microsystems]], given before Google was incorporated.{{Cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2004/04/29/MNGLD6CFND34.DTL |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090919030812/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=%2Fchronicle%2Farchive%2F2004%2F04%2F29%2FMNGLD6CFND34.DTL |archivedate=September 19, 2009 |title=For early Googlers, key word is $$$ |last=Kopytoff |first=Verne |date=April 29, 2004 |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |publisher=Hearst Communications |accessdate=February 19, 2010 |location=San Francisco |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} At least three other [[angel investor]]s invested in 1998: [[Amazon.com]] founder [[Jeff Bezos]], Stanford University computer science professor [[David Cheriton]], and entrepreneur [[Ram Shriram]]. Author Ken Auletta claims that each (including Bechtolsheim) invested $250,000,{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/Googled-End-World-As-Know/dp/0143118048/ref=la_B000APL8GA_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1480394430&sr=1-1|title=Googled: The End of the World As We Know It|last=Auletta|first=Ken|date=2010-10-26|publisher=Penguin Books|isbn=9780143118046|edition=Reprint|location=New York, N.Y.|language=English}} but other sources have reported a $100,000 level. After some additional, small investments through the end of 1998 to early 1999, a new, $25 million round of funding was announced on June 7, 1999,{{Cite press release|url=https://www.google.com/pressrel/pressrelease1.html|archiveurl=https://www.google.com/press/pressrel/pressrelease1.html |archivedate=March 9, 2000 |title=Google Receives $25 Million in Equity Funding |date=June 7, 1999 |location=Palo Alto, Calif. |publisher=Google |accessdate=February 16, 2009}} with major investors including the [[venture capital]] firms [[Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers]] and [[Sequoia Capital]]. Early in 1999, Brin and Page decided they wanted to sell Google to [[Excite]]. They went to Excite CEO George Bell and offered to sell it to him for $1 million. He rejected the offer. [[Vinod Khosla]], one of Excite's venture capitalists, talked the duo down to $750,000, but Bell still rejected it.{{cite web |first=MG |last=Siegler |title=When Google Wanted To Sell To Excite For Under $1 Million — And They Passed |url=https://techcrunch.com/2010/09/29/google-excite/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=September 29, 2010 |accessdate=November 29, 2016}} Google's [[initial public offering]] (IPO) took place five years later, on August 19, 2004. At that time Larry Page, Sergey Brin, and [[Eric Schmidt]] agreed to work together at Google for 20 years, until the year 2024.{{Cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/2008/01/18/news/companies/google.fortune/index.htm |title=Google wins again |date=January 29, 2008 |newspaper=Fortune |publisher=Time Warner |accessdate=January 22, 2011 |first=Adam |last=Lashinsky}} At IPO, the company offered 19,605,052 shares at a price of $85 per share.{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/aug2004/tc20040819_6843_tc120.htm|title=Google: Whiz Kids or Naughty Boys?|last=Elgin|first=Ben|date=August 19, 2004|newspaper=BusinessWeek|publisher=Bloomberg, L.P.|accessdate=February 19, 2010|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5hT7Hw63l?url=http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/aug2004/tc20040819_6843_tc120.htm|archivedate=June 12, 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://investor.google.com/pdf/2004_AnnualReport.pdf|title=2004 Annual Report|year=2004|website=Google, Inc.|page=29|accessdate=February 19, 2010|location=Mountain View, California}} Shares were sold in an online auction format using a system built by [[Morgan Stanley]] and [[Credit Suisse]], underwriters for the deal.{{Cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2004/04/29/technology/google/|title=Google sets $2.7 billion IPO |last=La Monica|first=Paul R.|date=April 30, 2004|work=CNN Money|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.zdnet.com/news/want-in-on-googles-ipo/135799|title=Want In on Google's IPO?|last=Kawamoto|first=Dawn|date=April 29, 2004|website=ZDNet|accessdate=February 19, 2010}} The sale of $1.67 bn (billion) gave Google a [[market capitalization]] of more than $23bn.{{Cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A14939-2004Aug19.html|title=Google's IPO: Grate Expectations|last=Webb|first=Cynthia L.|newspaper=The Washington Post|accessdate=February 19, 2010|location=Washington, D.C. | date=August 19, 2004}} By January 2014, its market capitalization had grown to $397bn.{{cite web|title=Google Overview|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/investing/stock/goog|website=Marketwatch|accessdate=February 2, 2014}} The vast majority of the 271 million shares remained under the control of Google, and many Google employees became instant paper millionaires. [[Yahoo!]], a competitor of Google's, also benefitted because it owned 8.4 million shares of Google before the IPO took place.{{Cite web|url=http://www.internetnews.com/bus-news/article.php/3392781|title=Yahoo and Google Settle|last=Kuchinskas|first=Susan|date=August 9, 2004|website=internetnews.com|accessdate=February 19, 2010}} There were concerns that Google's IPO would lead to changes in company culture. Reasons ranged from shareholder pressure for employee benefit reductions to the fact that many company executives would become instant paper millionaires.{{Cite news|agency=Associated Press |url=https://www.wired.com/techbiz/media/news/2004/04/63241 |title=Quirky Google Culture Endangered? |newspaper=Wired |date=April 28, 2004 |accessdate=November 27, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100814174333/http://www.wired.com/techbiz/media/news/2004/04/63241 |archivedate=August 14, 2010 }} As a reply to this concern, co-founders Brin and Page promised in a report to potential investors that the IPO would not change the company's culture.{{cite news |last1=Olsen |first1=Stefanie |last2=Kawamoto |first2=Dawn |url=http://news.cnet.com/2100-1024-5201978.html |title=Google IPO at $2.7 billion |work=[[CNET]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |date=April 30, 2004 |accessdate=November 27, 2010}} In 2005, articles in ''[[The New York Times]]'' and other sources began suggesting that Google had lost its anti-corporate, no evil philosophy.{{cite journal|author= Utz, Richard|title=The Good Corporation? Google's Medievalism and Why It Matters|journal= Studies in Medievalism|volume= 23 |date=2013|pages= 21-28}}{{cite web |first=Gary |last=Rivlin |title=Relax, Bill Gates; It's Google's Turn as the Villain |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/24/technology/relax-bill-gates-its-googles-turn-as-the-villain.html |website=[[The New York Times]] |date=August 24, 2005 |accessdate=March 9, 2017}}{{Cite news |last1=Gibson |first1=Owen |last2=Wray |first2=Richard |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/technology/search-giant-may-outgrow-its-fans/2005/08/25/1124562975596.html3001.asp |title=Search giant may outgrow its fans |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=August 25, 2005 |accessdate=November 27, 2010}}{{cite web |last=Ranka |first=Mohit |url=http://www.osnews.com/story/17928/Google--Dont-Be-Evil |title=Google – Don't Be Evil |publisher=OSNews |date=May 17, 2007 |accessdate=November 27, 2010}}{{Overcite|date=March 2017}} In an effort to maintain the company's unique culture, Google designated a Chief Culture Officer, who also serves as the Director of Human Resources. The purpose of the Chief Culture Officer is to develop and maintain the culture and work on ways to keep true to the core values that the company was founded on: a flat organization with a collaborative environment.{{cite web|last=Mills |first=Elinor |url=http://www.zdnet.com.au/meet-google-s-culture-czar-339275147.htm |title=Google's culture czar |website=ZDNet |date=April 30, 2007 |accessdate=November 27, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101031155723/http://www.zdnet.com.au/meet-google-s-culture-czar-339275147.htm |archivedate=October 31, 2010 }} Google has also faced allegations of [[sexism]] and [[ageism]] from former employees.{{cite news |last=Kawamoto |first=Dawn |url=http://news.cnet.com/Google-hit-with-job-discrimination-lawsuit/2100-1030_3-5807158.html?tag=nl |title=Google hit with job discrimination lawsuit |work=[[CNET]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |date=July 27, 2005 |accessdate=November 27, 2010}}{{cite web|title=Google accused of ageism in reinstated lawsuit |url=http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20071006/google_old_071006/20071006 |website=ctv.ca |4= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011205140/http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20071006/google_old_071006/20071006 |date=October 6, 2007 |archivedate=October 11, 2007 |accessdate=January 22, 2017 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} In 2013, a [[High-Tech Employee Antitrust Litigation|class action against]] several [[Silicon Valley]] companies, including Google, was filed for alleged "no cold call" agreements which restrained the recruitment of high-tech employees.{{cite web |first=Seth |last=Rosenblatt |title=Judge approves first payout in antitrust wage-fixing lawsuit |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/judge-approves-first-payout-in-antitrust-wage-fixing-lawsuit/ |website=[[CNET]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |date=May 16, 2014 |accessdate=January 22, 2017}} The stock performed well after the IPO, with shares hitting $350 for the first time on October 31, 2007,{{cite news |url=http://weblogs.baltimoresun.com/business/hancock/blog/2007/10/google_shares_hit_700.html |title=Google shares hit $700 |date=October 31, 2007 |last=Hancock |first=Jay |work=The Baltimore Sun |accessdate=November 27, 2010}} primarily because of strong sales and earnings in the [[online advertising]] market.{{Cite news |last=La Monica |first=Paul R. |url=http://money.cnn.com/2005/05/25/technology/techinvestor/lamonica/index.htm |title=Bowling for Google |work=CNN |date=May 25, 2005 |accessdate=February 28, 2007}} The surge in stock price was fueled mainly by individual investors, as opposed to large institutional investors and [[mutual fund]]s. GOOG shares split into GOOG Class C shares and GOOGL class A shares.{{cite web|title = This could cost Google more than $500 million|url = http://www.cnbc.com/2015/04/02/stock-split-could-cost-google-over-500-million.html|website = CNBC|accessdate = December 30, 2015}} The company is listed on the [[NASDAQ]] stock exchange under the [[ticker symbol]]s GOOGL and GOOG, and on the [[Frankfurt Stock Exchange]] under the ticker symbol GGQ1. These ticker symbols now refer to Alphabet Inc., Google's holding company, since the fourth quarter of 2015.{{Cite news|first=Jacob |last=Pramuk |url=http://www.cnbc.com/2015/08/10/google-announces-plans-for-new-operating-structure.html |title=Google to become part of new company, Alphabet |date=August 10, 2015 |accessdate=August 11, 2015 |newspaper=[[CNBC]]}} ===Growth=== In March 1999, the company moved its offices to [[Palo Alto, California]], which is home to several prominent [[Silicon Valley]] technology start-ups.{{Cite news|url=http://news.cnet.com/2100-1040-960790.html|title=A building blessed with tech success|last=Fried|first=Ian|date=October 4, 2002|work=[[CNET]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=February 15, 2010}} The next year, against Page and Brin's initial opposition toward an advertising-funded search engine,{{Cite book|last=Stross|first=Randall|title=Planet Google: One Company's Audacious Plan to Organize Everything We Know|publisher=Free Press|location=New York|date=September 2008|pages=3–4|chapter=Introduction|isbn=978-1-4165-4691-7|url=https://books.google.com/?id=xOk3EIUW9VgC&printsec=frontcover|accessdate=February 14, 2010|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/?id=xOk3EIUW9VgC&printsec=frontcover}} Google began selling advertisements associated with search keywords. In order to maintain an uncluttered page design and increase speed, advertisements were solely text-based. Keywords were sold based on a combination of price bids and click-throughs, with bidding starting at five cents per click. This model of selling keyword advertising was first pioneered by Goto.com, an [[Idealab]] spin-off created by [[Bill Gross (entrepreneur)|Bill Gross]].{{Cite web|url=http://searchenginewatch.com/2166331 |title=GoTo Going Strong |last=Sullivan |first=Danny |date=July 1, 1998 |website=SearchEngineWatch |accessdate=February 18, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091014204451/http://searchenginewatch.com/2166331 |archivedate=October 14, 2009 }}{{Cite news|url=http://news.cnet.com/Pay-for-placement-gets-another-shot/2100-1023_3-208309.html|title=Pay-for-placement gets another shot|last=Pelline|first=Jeff|date=February 19, 1998|work=[[CNET]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=February 18, 2010}} When the company changed names to Overture Services, it sued Google over alleged infringements of the company's pay-per-click and bidding patents. Overture Services would later be bought by Yahoo! and renamed [[Yahoo! Search Marketing]]. The case was then settled out of court; Google agreed to issue shares of common stock to Yahoo! in exchange for a perpetual license.{{Cite news|url=http://news.cnet.com/Google,-Yahoo-bury-the-legal-hatchet/2100-1024_3-5302421.html|title=Google, Yahoo bury the legal hatchet|last=Olsen|first=Stephanie|date=August 9, 2004|work=[[CNET]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=February 18, 2010}} In 2001, Google received a patent for its PageRank mechanism.{{Ref patent |country=US |number=6285999 |status=patent |title=Method for node ranking in a linked database |gdate=September 4, 2001 |fdate=January 9, 1998 |invent1=Page, Lawrence |assign1=The Board of Trustees of the Leland Stanford Junior University |class=G06F17/30}} The patent was officially assigned to Stanford University and lists Lawrence Page as the inventor. In 2003, after outgrowing two other locations, the company leased an office complex from [[Silicon Graphics]], at 1600 Amphitheatre Parkway in [[Mountain View, California]].{{Cite news|url=http://news.cnet.com/Googles-movin-on-up/2110-1032_3-1025111.html|title=Google's movin' on up|last=Olsen|first=Stephanie|date=July 11, 2003|work=[[CNET]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=February 15, 2010}} The complex became known as the [[Googleplex]], a play on the word [[googolplex]], the number one followed by a googol zeroes. The [[Googleplex]] interiors were designed by [[Clive Wilkinson]] Architects. Three years later, Google bought the property from SGI for $319 million.{{Cite news|url=http://sanjose.bizjournals.com/sanjose/stories/2006/06/19/newscolumn3.html|title=Google to buy headquarters building from Silicon Graphics|date=June 16, 2006|newspaper=Silicon Valley / San Jose Business Journal|publisher=American City Business Journals|accessdate=February 15, 2010|location=San Jose}} By that time, the name "Google" had found its way into everyday language, causing the verb "[[google (verb)|google]]" to be added to the ''[[Merriam-Webster]] Collegiate Dictionary'' and the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'', denoted as: "to use the Google search engine to obtain information on the Internet".{{cite web|url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2006/10/do-you-google.html|title=Do You "Google"?|last=Krantz|first=Michael|date=October 25, 2006|website=Google, Inc.|accessdate=February 17, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://msnbc.msn.com/id/13720643/|title=To Google or Not to Google|last=Bylund|first=Anders|date=July 5, 2006|website=msnbc.com|accessdate=February 17, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060707062623/http://msnbc.msn.com/id/13720643/|archivedate=July 7, 2006}} The first use of "Google" as a verb in [[pop culture]] happened on the tV series ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]'', in 2002.{{cite news|work=The Atlantic||url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2014/06/the-first-use-of-the-verb-to-google-on-television-buffy-the-vampire-slayer/373599/|title=The First Use of 'to Google' on Television? Buffy the Vampire Slayer|last=Meyer|first=Robinson|language=en-US|access-date=2016-09-28}} In 2005, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' reported on a 700 percent increase in third-quarter profit for Google, largely thanks to large companies shifting their advertising strategies from newspapers, magazines, and television to the Internet.{{cite news |first=David |last=Vise |title=Online Ads Give Google Huge Gain in Profit |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/10/20/AR2005102002058.html |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=October 21, 2005 |accessdate=November 27, 2016}} In January 2008, all the data that passed through Google's MapReduce software component had an aggregated size of 20 [[petabyte]]s per day.{{cite web |first1=Jeffrey |last1=Dean |first2=Sanjay |last2=Ghemawat |title=MapReduce: simplified data processing on large clusters |url=http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?doid=1327452.1327492 |website=ACM Digital Library |date=January 1, 2008 |accessdate=December 6, 2016}}{{cite web |first=Grzegorz |last=Czajkowski |title=Sorting 1PB with MapReduce |url=https://googleblog.blogspot.no/2008/11/sorting-1pb-with-mapreduce.html |website=Official Google Blog |publisher=Google |date=November 21, 2008 |accessdate=December 6, 2016}}{{cite web |first=Erick |last=Schonfeld |title=Google Processing 20,000 Terabytes A Day, And Growing |url=https://techcrunch.com/2008/01/09/google-processing-20000-terabytes-a-day-and-growing/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=January 9, 2008 |accessdate=December 6, 2016}} In 2009, a [[CNN]] report about top political searches of 2009 noted that "more than a billion searches" are being typed into Google on a daily basis.{{cite web |first=Eric |last=Kuhn |title=Google unveils top political searches of 2009 |url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2009/12/18/google-unveils-top-political-searches-of-2009/ |website=[[CNN]] |date=December 18, 2009 |accessdate=December 6, 2016}} In May 2011, the number of monthly unique visitors to Google surpassed one billion for the first time, an 8.4 percent increase from May 2010 (931 million).{{cite web |author=Ben |title=Google's new record, 1 billion visitors in May |url=http://itsalltech.com/2011/06/22/googles-new-record-1-billion-visitors-in-may/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116035631/http://itsalltech.com/2011/06/22/googles-new-record-1-billion-visitors-in-may/ |website=It's All Tech |date=June 2, 2011 |archivedate=January 16, 2013 |accessdate=November 30, 2016}} 2012 marked the first year that Google generated $50 billion in annual revenue, topping 2011's $38 billion generated. Then-CEO Larry Page commented in January 2013: "We ended 2012 with a strong quarter ... Revenues were up 36% year-on-year, and 8% quarter-on-quarter. And we hit $50 billion in revenues for the first time last year – not a bad achievement in just a decade and a half."{{cite web |first=Seth |last=Fiegerman |title=Google Has Its First $50 Billion Year |url=http://mashable.com/2013/01/22/google-q4-earnings/#42cbeRCbSkqH |website=[[Mashable]] |date=January 22, 2013 |accessdate=November 30, 2016}} ===2013 onward=== [[File:Google logo 2014.tiff|thumb|Screenshot of the Google homepage in 2015]] Google announced the launch of a new company, called [[Calico (company)|Calico]], on September 19, 2013, to be led by [[Apple, Inc.]] chairman [[Arthur D. Levinson|Arthur Levinson]]. In the official public statement, Page explained that the "health and well-being" company would focus on "the challenge of ageing and associated diseases".{{cite news|title=Google spin-off Calico to search for answers to ageing|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-24158924|accessdate=September 20, 2013|newspaper=BBC News|date=September 19, 2013|author=Jane Wakefield}} Google celebrated its 15-year anniversary on September 27, 2013, and in 2016 it celebrated its 18th birthday with an animated [[Doodle]] shown on web browsers around the world.{{cite news|title=Google celebrates 18th birthday with a Doodle - amid some confusion over the correct date|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/2016/09/26/when-is-googles-birthday/|accessdate=27 September 2016|work=[[Daily Telegraph]]|publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited}} although it has used other dates for its official birthday.{{cite web|url=http://searchengineland.com/google-is-10-years-old-finding-the-real-google-birthday-12172|website=searchengineland.com|title=Google Is 10 Years Old? Finding The Real Google Birthday|last=Sullivan|first=Danny|date=September 14, 2007|accessdate=September 28, 2013}} The reason for the choice of September 27 remains unclear, and a dispute with rival search engine [[Yahoo! Search]] in 2005 has been suggested as the cause.{{Cite news |last=Peterson |first=Andrea|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2013/09/27/is-today-really-googles-birthday/ |title=Is today really Google's birthday? |newspaper=Washington Post|date=September 27, 2013 |accessdate=September 28, 2013}}{{cite news|title=Google celebrates 15th birthday with interactive piñata 'doodle'|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/google-celebrates-15th-birthday-with-interactive-piata-doodle-8842436.html|accessdate=September 28, 2013|newspaper=The Independent|date=September 26, 2013|author=John Hall|location=London}} The [[Alliance for Affordable Internet]] (A4AI) was launched in October 2013; Google is part of the coalition of public and private organisations that also includes [[Facebook]], [[Intel]], and [[Microsoft]]. Led by [[Sir Tim Berners-Lee]], the A4AI seeks to make Internet access more affordable so that access is broadened in the developing world, where only 31% of people are online. Google will help to decrease Internet access prices so they fall below the UN Broadband Commission's worldwide target of 5% of monthly income.{{cite web |first=Samuel |last=Gibbs |title=Sir Tim Berners-Lee and Google lead coalition for cheaper internet |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2013/oct/07/google-berners-lee-alliance-broadband-africa |website=[[The Guardian]] |publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]] |date=October 7, 2013 |accessdate=March 15, 2017}} The corporation's consolidated revenue for the third quarter of 2013 was reported in mid-October 2013 as $14.89 billion, a 12 percent increase compared to the previous quarter.{{cite web |first=Ryan |last=Whitwam |title=Google Beats Analyst Estimates For Third Quarter Results, Stock Passes $1000 Per Share |url=http://www.androidpolice.com/2013/10/18/google-beats-analyst-estimates-for-third-quarter-results-stock-passes-1000-per-share/ |website=Android Police |date=October 18, 2013 |accessdate=March 15, 2017}} Google's Internet business was responsible for $10.8 billion of this total, with an increase in the number of users' clicks on advertisements.{{cite news|title=Google earnings up 12% in third quarter even as Motorola losses deepen|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2013/oct/17/google-q3-revenue-earnings-report|accessdate=October 18, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=October 17, 2013|author=Reuters}} {{dead link|date=March 2017}} In November 2013, Google announced plans for a new 1-million-sq-ft (93,000 sq m) office in London, which was due to open in 2016. The new premises, able to accommodate 4,500 employees, has been identified as one of the biggest ever commercial property acquisitions in Britain.{{cite web |first=Leo |last=Mirani |title=Inside Google’s new 1-million-square-foot London office—three years before it’s ready |url=https://qz.com/139794/inside-googles-new-1-million-square-foot-london-office-three-years-before-its-ready/ |website=[[Quartz (publication)|Quartz]] |publisher=[[Atlantic Media]] |date=November 1, 2013 |accessdate=March 15, 2017}} According to [[Interbrand]]'s annual Best Global Brands report, Google has been the second most valuable brand in the world (behind [[Apple Inc.]]) in 2013,{{cite web|title=Rankings - 2013 - Best Global Brands - Interbrand|url=http://interbrand.com/best-brands/best-global-brands/2013/ranking/#?listFormat=ls|website=Interbrand|accessdate=October 23, 2016}} 2014,{{cite web|title=Rankings - 2014 - Best Global Brands - Interbrand|url=http://interbrand.com/best-brands/best-global-brands/2014/ranking/#?listFormat=ls|website=Interbrand|accessdate=October 23, 2016}} 2015,{{cite web|title=Rankings - 2015 - Best Global Brands - Interbrand|url=http://interbrand.com/best-brands/best-global-brands/2015/ranking/#?listFormat=ls|website=Interbrand|accessdate=October 23, 2016}} and 2016, with a valuation of $133 billion.{{cite web|title=Rankings - 2016 - Best Global Brands |url=http://interbrand.com/best-brands/best-global-brands/2016/ranking/#?listFormat=ls|website=Interbrand|accessdate=October 23, 2016}} In September 2015, Google engineering manager Rachel Potvin revealed details about Google's software code at an engineering conference. She revealed that the entire Google codebase, which spans every single service it develops, consists of over 2 billion lines of code. All that code is stored on a code repository available to all 25,000 Google engineers, and the code is regularly copied and updated on 10 Google data centers. To keep control, Potvin said Google has built its own "version control system", called "Piper", and that "when you start a new project, you have a wealth of libraries already available to you. Almost everything has already been done." Engineers can make a single code change and deploy it on all services at the same time. The only major exceptions are that the PageRank search results algorithm is stored separately with only specific employee access, and the code for the Android operating system and the Google Chrome browser are also stored separately, as they don't run on the Internet. The "Piper" system spans 85 [[Terabyte|TB]] of data. Google engineers make 25,000 changes to the code each day, and on a weekly basis change approximately 15 million lines of code across 250,000 files. With that much code, automated bots have to help. Potvin reported, "You need to make a concerted effort to maintain code health. And this is not just humans maintaining code health, but robots too.” Bots aren't writing code, but generating a lot of the data and configuration files needed to run the company’s software. "Not only is the size of the repository increasing," Potvin explained, "but the rate of change is also increasing. This is an exponential curve."{{cite web|first=Cade|last=Metz|title=Google is 2 billion lines of code - and it's all in one place|url=https://www.wired.com/2015/09/google-2-billion-lines-codeand-one-place/|website=Wired|date=September 16, 2015|accessdate=October 23, 2016}}{{cite web |first=Andrew |last=Tarantola |title=Google's codebase is ludicrously huge for good reason |url=https://www.engadget.com/2015/09/18/googles-codebase-is-ludicrously-huge-for-good-reason/ |website=[[Engadget]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=September 18, 2015 |accessdate=October 23, 2016}} As of October 2016, Google operates 70 offices in more than 40 countries.{{cite web|title=Google locations|url=https://www.google.com/about/company/facts/locations/|website=Google, Inc.|accessdate=October 23, 2016}} [[Alexa Internet|Alexa]], a company that monitors commercial web traffic, lists Google.com as the most visited website in the world.{{cite web |title=google.com Traffic Statistics |url=http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/google.com |website=[[Alexa Internet]] |date=November 25, 2016 |accessdate=November 27, 2016}} Several other Google services also figure in the top 100 most visited websites, including YouTube{{cite web |title=youtube.com Traffic Statistics |url=http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/youtube.com |website=[[Alexa Internet]] |date=November 25, 2016 |accessdate=November 27, 2016}} and Blogger.{{cite web |title=blogger.com Traffic Statistics |url=http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/blogger.com |website=[[Alexa Internet]] |date=November 25, 2016 |accessdate=November 27, 2016}} ====Push into hardware==== In April 2016, ''[[Recode]]'' reported that Google had hired Rick Osterloh, [[Motorola Mobility]]'s former President, to head Google's new hardware division.{{cite web |first1=Mark |last1=Bergen |first2=Ina |last2=Fried |title=Google is building a new hardware division under former Motorola chief Rick Osterloh |url=http://www.recode.net/2016/4/28/11586518/google-hardware-division-rick-osterloh |website=[[Recode]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=April 28, 2016 |accessdate=October 9, 2016}} Later, in October 2016, ''The Information'' reported that David Foster, [[Amazon.com]]'s former [[Amazon Kindle|Kindle]] hardware chief, had joined Google as hardware chief for a new brand of smartphones by Google.{{cite web |first=Kevin |last=McLaughlin |title=Google Hires Amazon’s Former Kindle Hardware Chief |url=https://www.theinformation.com/google-hires-amazons-former-kindle-hardware-chief |website=The Information |date=October 3, 2016 |accessdate=October 9, 2016}} On October 4, 2016, Google held a press event, where it announced its intention to create more hardware. Rick Osterloh stated: "a lot of the innovation that we want to do now ends up requiring controlling the end-to-end user experience",{{cite web |first=Dieter |last=Bohn |title=The Google Phone |url=http://www.theverge.com/a/google-pixel-phone-new-hardware-interview-2016 |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |accessdate=October 9, 2016}} and introduced: * The [[Pixel (smartphone)|Pixel and Pixel XL]] smartphones with the [[Google Assistant]], a next-generation contextual voice assistant, built-in.{{cite web |first=Vlad |last=Savov |title=Pixel ‘phone by Google’ announced |url=http://www.theverge.com/2016/10/4/13161028/google-phone-announced-pixel-xl-price-release-date-specs |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=October 4, 2016 |accessdate=October 8, 2016}} * [[Google Home]], an [[Amazon Echo]]-like voice assistant placed in the house that can answer voice queries, play music, find information from apps (calendar, weather etc.), and control third-party smart home appliances (users can tell it to turn on the lights, for example).{{cite web |first=Dieter |last=Bohn |title=Google Home is smart, loud, and kind of cute |url=http://www.theverge.com/2016/10/4/13156676/google-home-assistant-speaker-photos-video-device-hands-on |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=October 4, 2016 |accessdate=October 8, 2016}} * [[Google Daydream|Daydream View]] [[virtual reality]] headset that lets [[Android (operating system)|Android]] users with compatible Daydream-ready smartphones put their phones in the headset and enjoy VR content.{{cite web |first1=Adi |last1=Robertson |first2=Jacob |last2=Kastrenakes |title=Google's Daydream View VR headset goes on sale next month for $79 |url=http://www.theverge.com/2016/10/4/13161506/google-vr-headset-photos-daydream-view-virtual-reality |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=October 4, 2016 |accessdate=October 8, 2016}} * [[Google Wifi]], a connected set of [[Wi-Fi]] routers to simplify and extend coverage of home Wi-Fi.{{cite web |first=Dieter |last=Bohn |title=The Google Wifi routers are little white pucks you can scatter throughout your house |url=http://www.theverge.com/2016/10/4/13157680/google-wifi-router-photos-hands-on |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=October 4, 2016 |accessdate=October 8, 2016}} ===Acquisitions and partnerships=== {{See also|List of mergers and acquisitions by Google}}Google went through three major periods of acquisitions, spanning 2000–2009, 2010–2012, and 2014–2015.[[File:Google page brin.jpg|thumb|left|[[Larry Page]] and [[Sergey Brin]] in 2003|220x220px]] ==== 2000–2009 ==== Since 2001, Google has acquired many companies, primarily small venture capital-funded firms. In 2004, Google acquired [[Keyhole, Inc]].{{Cite press release |title=Google Acquires Keyhole Corp |publisher=Google, Inc. |date=October 27, 2004 |url=https://www.google.com/press/pressrel/keyhole.html |accessdate=November 27, 2010}} The start-up company developed a product called Earth Viewer that gave a [[3D computer graphics|three-dimensional]] view of the Earth. Google renamed the service [[Google Earth]] in 2005. Google acquired [[Urchin (software)|Urchin Software]] in April 2005, using their Urchin on Demand product (along with ideas from Adaptive Path's Measure Map) to create [[Google Analytics]] in 2006. In October 2006, Google announced that it had acquired the video-sharing site YouTube for $1.65 billion in Google stock,{{cite web |first=Michael |last=Arrington |title=Google Has Acquired YouTube |url=https://techcrunch.com/2006/10/09/google-has-acquired-youtube/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=October 9, 2006 |accessdate=March 15, 2017}}{{cite web |first1=Andrew Ross |last1=Sorkin |first2=Jeremy W. |last2=Peters |title=Google to Acquire YouTube for $1.65 Billion |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/09/business/09cnd-deal.html |website=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 9, 2006 |accessdate=March 15, 2017}} and the deal was finalized on November 13, 2006.{{cite web |first=Michael |last=Arrington |title=Google Closes YouTube Acquisition |url=https://techcrunch.com/2006/11/13/google-closes-youtube-acquisition/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=November 13, 2006 |accessdate=March 15, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Eric |last=Auchard |title=Google closes YouTube deal |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/us-google-idUSWEN973120061114 |website=[[Reuters]] |publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] |date=November 14, 2006 |accessdate=March 15, 2017}} Google does not provide detailed figures for YouTube's running costs, and YouTube's revenues in 2007 were noted as "[[materiality (auditing)|not material]]" in a regulatory filing.{{Cite news|first=Yi-Wyn |last=Yen |date=March 25, 2008 |url=http://techland.blogs.fortune.cnn.com/2008/03/25/youtube-looks-for-the-money-clip |title=YouTube Looks For the Money Clip |accessdate=July 5, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100117010826/http://techland.blogs.fortune.cnn.com/2008/03/25/youtube-looks-for-the-money-clip/ |archivedate=January 17, 2010 }} In May 2008, a ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine article projected the 2008 YouTube revenue at $200 million, noting progress in advertising sales.{{cite web |first1=Quentin |last1=Hardy |first2=Evan |last2=Hessel |title=GooTube |url=https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2008/0616/050.html |website=[[Forbes]] |date=May 29, 2008 |accessdate=March 15, 2017}} On April 13, 2007, Google reached an agreement to acquire [[DoubleClick]] for $3.1 billion, transferring to Google valuable relationships that DoubleClick had with Web publishers and advertising agencies.{{cite web |first1=Louise |last1=Story |first2=Miguel |last2=Helft |title=Google Buys DoubleClick for $3.1 Billion |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/14/technology/14DoubleClick.html |website=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 14, 2007 |accessdate=March 9, 2017}} Later that same year, Google purchased [[GrandCentral]] for $50 million.{{cite web|url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2007/07/all-aboard.html|title=All aboard|last=Chan|first=Wesley|date=July 2, 2007|website=Google, Inc.|accessdate=February 26, 2010}} The site would later be renamed [[Google Voice]]. On August 5, 2009, Google bought out its first public company, video software maker [[On2 Technologies]], for $106.5 million.{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/intl/en/press/pressrel/ir_20090805.html|title=Google to Acquire On2 Technologies|website=Google Press release|date=August 5, 2009|accessdate=July 5, 2010}} Google also acquired [[Aardvark (search engine)|Aardvark]], a social networking search engine, for $50 million, and commented on its internal blog, "we're looking forward to collaborating to see where we can take it".{{cite web|accessdate=February 12, 2010 |url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2010/02/google-acquires-aardvark.html |title=Google Acquires Aardvark |website=Google, Inc. |quote=we're excited to announce that we've acquired Aardvark, a unique technology company.}} In April 2010, Google announced it had acquired a hardware startup, Agnilux.{{cite web |url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/google-buys-stealthy-start-up-agnilux-2010-04-21 |title=Google buys stealthy start-up Agnilux |date=April 21, 2010 |last=Letzing |first=John |website=MarketWatch |accessdate=November 27, 2010}} In addition to the many companies Google has purchased, the firm has partnered with other organizations for research, advertising, and other activities. For example, in 2005, Google partnered with [[NASA]] [[Ames Research Center]] to build {{convert|1000000|sqft|m2|-3}} of offices.{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/Can-Google-beat-the-new-office-curse/2100-1030_3-5884957.html|title=Can Google beat the new-office curse?|last=Mills|first=Elinor|date=September 29, 2005|website=[[CNET]] |accessdate=February 26, 2010}} The offices would be used for research projects involving large-scale data management, [[nanotechnology]], [[distributed computing]], and the [[entrepreneurial space industry]]. Google entered into a partnership with [[Sun Microsystems]], in October 2005, to help share and distribute each other's technologies.{{Cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/tech/news/2005-10-03-google-sun-team_x.htm|title=Google, Sun make 'big deal' together|last=Kessler|first=Michelle|last2=Acohido|first2=Byron|date=October 3, 2005|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|publisher=[[Gannett Co. Inc.]]|accessdate=February 26, 2010}} The company also partnered with [[AOL]]{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/What-the-Google-AOL-deal-means-for-users/2100-1024_3-6010327.html|title=What the Google-AOL deal means for users|last=Mills|first=Elinor|date=December 28, 2005|website=[[CNET]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=February 26, 2010}} to enhance each other's [[video search]] services. Google's 2005 partnerships also included financing the new [[.mobi]] [[top-level domain]] for mobile devices, along with other companies including [[Microsoft]], [[Nokia]], and [[Ericsson]].{{cite web|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/DotMobi-Sells-Mobi-DomainName-paidcontent-2969792871.html?x=0&.v=1|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110623143032/https://finance.yahoo.com/news/DotMobi-Sells-Mobi-DomainName-paidcontent-2969792871.html?x=0&.v=1|archivedate=June 23, 2011|title=DotMobi Sells .Mobi Domain-Name Operator|last=Lunden|first=Ingrid|date=February 12, 2010|website=[[Yahoo!]]|accessdate=February 26, 2010}} Google would later launch "[[AdSense for Mobile]]", taking advantage of the emerging mobile advertising market.{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/intl/en/press/annc/20070917_mobileads.html|title=Google AdSense for Mobile unlocks the potential of the mobile advertising market|date=September 17, 2007|website=Google, Inc.|accessdate=February 26, 2010}} Further extending its advertising reach, Google and [[Fox Sports Digital Media|Fox Interactive Media]] of [[News Corporation]] entered into a $900 million agreement to provide search and advertising on the then-popular social networking site [[MySpace]].{{cite web |title=Fox Interactive Media Enters Into Landmark Agreement with Google Inc. |url=http://googlepress.blogspot.no/2006/08/fox-interactive-media-enters-into_07.html |website=News from Google |publisher=Google |date=August 7, 2006 |accessdate=January 22, 2017}} In 2007, Google began sponsoring [[NORAD Tracks Santa]], displacing the former sponsor AOL. NORAD Tracks Santa purports to follow [[Santa Claus]]' progress on [[Christmas Eve]],{{cite web |url=http://searchengineland.com/tracking-santa-norad-google-team-up-for-christmas-12817 |title=Tracking Santa: NORAD & Google Team Up For Christmas, Dec 1, 2007, Danny Sullivan |accessdate=July 5, 2010 |website=Search Engine Land}} using Google Earth to "track Santa" in 3-D for the first time.{{cite news |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13772_3-10418101-52.html |title=Behind the scenes: NORAD's Santa tracker for Thur, Dec 21, 2009 By Daniel Terdiman, CNET |accessdate=December 31, 2009 |work=[[CNET]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]}} Google-owned YouTube gave NORAD Tracks Santa its own channel.{{cite web |url=http://searchengineland.com/instructions-on-tracking-santa-with-norad-google-the-2007-edition-13001 |title=Instructions On Tracking Santa With NORAD & Google: The 2007 Edition, Dec 24, 2007, Danny Sullivan |accessdate=July 5, 2010 |website=Search Engine Land}} In 2008, Google developed a partnership with [[GeoEye]] to launch a satellite providing Google with high-resolution (0.41 m monochrome, 1.65 m color) imagery for Google Earth. The satellite was launched from [[Vandenberg Air Force Base]] on September 6, 2008.{{Cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2008/09/06/us-geoeye-idUSN0633403420080906|title=GeoEye launches high-resolution satellite|last=Shalal-Esa|first=Andrea|date=September 6, 2008|work=Reuters|accessdate=February 26, 2010|location=Washington}} Google also announced in 2008 that it was hosting an archive of ''[[Life (magazine)|Life Magazine]]'''s photographs. Some images in the archive were never published in the magazine.{{Cite news |title=Google gives online life to Life mag's photos |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/27802744/ |quote=Google Inc. has opened an online photo gallery that will include millions of images from ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' magazine's archives that have never been seen by the public before |work=[[Associated Press]] |date=November 20, 2008 |accessdate=February 25, 2010 |location=Mountain View, California}} The photos were [[watermark]]ed and originally had copyright notices posted on all photos, regardless of [[public domain]] status.{{cite web |url=http://searchengineland.com/google-to-host-10-million-time-life-unpublished-images-15513 |title=Google Hosting Time-Life Photo Archive, 10 Million Unpublished Images Now Live |website=[[Search Engine Land]] |author=Greg Stirling |date=November 18, 2008 |accessdate=July 5, 2010}} ==== 2010–2012 ==== In 2010, [[Google Energy]] made its first investment in a [[renewable energy]] project, putting $38.8 million into two [[wind farm]]s in [[North Dakota]]. The company announced the two locations will generate 169.5 megawatts of power, enough to supply 55,000 homes. The farms, which were developed by [[NextEra Energy Resources]], will reduce fossil fuel use in the region and return profits. NextEra Energy Resources sold Google a twenty-percent stake in the project to get funding for its development.{{Cite news |title=Google Invests in Two Wind Farms |first1=Scott |last1=Morrison |first2=Cassandra |last2=Sweet |newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=May 4, 2010 |url=https://www.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704342604575222420304732394.html |accessdate=November 27, 2010}} In February 2010, the [[Federal Energy Regulatory Commission]] FERC granted Google an authorization to buy and sell energy at market rates.{{cite news|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-11128_3-10456435-54.html|title=Google Energy can now buy and sell energy|work=Cnet.com}} The order specifically states that Google Energy—a subsidiary of Google—holds the rights "for the sale of energy, capacity, and ancillary services at market-based rates", but acknowledges that neither Google Energy nor its affiliates "own or control any generation or transmission" facilities.{{cite news|title=Google gets go-ahead to buy, sell energy|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-11128_3-10456435-54.html|work=[[CNET]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=September 23, 2013|author=Candace Lombardi|date=February 19, 2010}} The corporation exercised this authorization in September 2013 when it announced it would purchase all the electricity produced by the not-yet-built 240-megawatt Happy Hereford wind farm.{{cite news|title=Google is on the way to quietly becoming an electric utility|url=http://qz.com/125407/google-is-on-the-way-to-quietly-becoming-an-electric-utility/|accessdate=September 23, 2013|newspaper=Quartz|date=September 18, 2013|author=Todd Woody}} Also in 2010, Google purchased [[Global IP Solutions]], a Norway-based company that provides web-based [[teleconferencing]] and other related services. This acquisition enabled Google to add telephone-style services to its list of products.{{Cite news |last1=Gomes |first1=Lee |date=May 18, 2010 |title=Google's Latest Telephony Play |work=[[Forbes]]|url=http://www.forbes.com/2010/05/18/google-microsoft-videoconferencing-technology-telephony.html |accessdate=November 27, 2010}} On May 27, 2010, Google announced it had also closed the acquisition of the mobile ad network [[AdMob]]. This occurred days after the [[Federal Trade Commission]] closed its investigation into the purchase.{{cite web |url=http://www.appscout.com/2010/05/google_closes_acquisition_of_a.php |title=Google Closes Acquisition of AdMob |last1=Albanesius |first1=Chloe |date=May 27, 2010 |website=AppScout|accessdate=June 16, 2010}} Google acquired the company for an undisclosed amount.{{cite news |url=http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2355609,00.asp |title=Google Acquires Mobile Display Ad Firm AdMob |last1=Albanesius |first1=Chloe |date=November 9, 2010 |work=PC Magazine |publisher=Ziff Davis Publishing Holdings Inc. |accessdate=June 16, 2010}} In July 2010, Google signed an agreement with an Iowa wind farm to buy 114 megawatts of energy for 20 years.{{cite web|url=http://news.techworld.com/green-it/3232690/google-buys-power-from-iowa-wind-farm/?olo=rss |title=Google buys power from Iowa wind farm|website=News.techworld.com |date=July 21, 2010 |accessdate=October 26, 2010}} On April 4, 2011, ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' reported that Google bid $900 million for 6000 [[Nortel Networks]] patents.{{cite news |url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/google-bids-900-million-for-nortel-patents/article1969788/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110407100606/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/google-bids-900-million-for-nortel-patents/article1969788/ |archivedate=April 7, 2011 |title=Bid for Nortel patents marks Google's new push into mobile world |work=Globe and Mail |date= April 4, 2011|accessdate=April 25, 2011 |location=Toronto}} On August 15, 2011, Google made its largest-ever acquisition to-date when it announced that it would acquire [[Motorola Mobility]] for $12.5 billion{{cite news |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/faster-forward/post/google-agrees-to-acquire-motorola-mobility/2011/08/15/gIQABmTkGJ_blog.html |title=Google agrees to acquire Motorola Mobility |author=Tsukayama, Hayley |work=The Washington Post |date=August 15, 2011 |accessdate=August 17, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://investor.google.com/releases/2011/0815.html |title=Google to Acquire Motorola Mobility — Google Investor Relations |website=Google |accessdate=August 17, 2011}} subject to approval from regulators in the United States and Europe. In a post on Google's blog, Google Chief Executive and co-founder Larry Page revealed that the acquisition was a strategic move to strengthen Google's patent portfolio. The company's Android operating system has come under fire in an industry-wide patent battle, as Apple and Microsoft have sued Android device makers such as HTC, Samsung, and Motorola.{{cite web|last=Hughes |first=Neil |url=http://www.appleinsider.com/articles/11/08/15/google_ceo_anticompetitive_apple_microsoft_forced_motorola_deal.html |title=Google CEO: 'Anticompetitive' Apple, Microsoft forced Motorola deal |website=AppleInsider |accessdate=August 17, 2011}} The merger was completed on May 22, 2012, after the approval of [[People's Republic of China]].{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-18164190|title=Google |accessdate=May 23, 2012 | work=BBC News|date=May 22, 2012}} This purchase was made in part to help Google gain Motorola's considerable patent portfolio on mobile phones and wireless technologies, to help protect Google in its ongoing patent disputes with other companies,{{cite web|last=Page |first=Larry |url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2011/08/supercharging-android-google-to-acquire.html |title=Official Google Blog: Supercharging Android: Google to Acquire Motorola Mobility |website=Google Blog at Blogspot.com |accessdate=August 17, 2011}} mainly [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] and [[Microsoft]], and to allow it to continue to freely offer [[Android (operating system)|Android]].{{cite web|title=Google to buy Motorola Mobility for $12.5B|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1035_3-20092362-94/google-to-buy-motorola-mobility-for-$12.5b/|first=Roger|last=Cheng|date=August 15, 2011|website=CNet News}} After the acquisition closed, Google began to restructure the Motorola business to fit Google's strategy. On August 13, 2012, Google announced plans to lay off 4000 Motorola Mobility employees.{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/08/13/us-motorolamobility-jobs-idUSBRE87C07F20120813 | title= Google to cut 4,000 Motorola Mobility jobs, shares rise | date=August 13, 2012 | work=Reuters}} On December 10, 2012, Google sold the manufacturing operations of Motorola Mobility to [[Flextronics]] for $75 million.{{cite web |first=Daniel |last=Cooper |title=Motorola's retreat continues, sells factories in China and Brazil to Flextronics for $75 million |url=https://www.engadget.com/2012/12/11/motorola-flextronics/ |website=[[Engadget]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=December 11, 2012 |accessdate=March 9, 2017}} As a part of the agreement, Flextronics will manufacture undisclosed Android and other mobile devices.{{cite news|url=http://www.zdnet.com/cn/flextronics-acquires-motorola-mobilitys-plants-in-china-brazil-7000008603/ | title= Flextronics acquires Motorola Mobility's plants in China, Brazil |work=ZDNet| date=December 11, 2012}} On December 19, 2012, Google sold the Motorola Home business division of Motorola Mobility to [[Arris Group]] for $2.35 billion in a cash-and-stock transaction. As a part of this deal, Google acquired a 15.7% stake in Arris Group valued at $300 million.{{cite web|website=arrisi.com|url=http://www.arrisi.com/_docs/ARRIS_Announcement_Release.pdf | title= Arris To Acquire Motorola Home Business For $2.35 Billion In Cash And Stock | date=December 19, 2012}} On June 5, 2012, Google announced it had acquired [[Quickoffice]], a company widely known for their mobile productivity suite for both iOS and Android. Google plans to integrate Quickoffice's technology into its own product suite.{{cite web |first=Frederic |last=Lardinois |title=Google Acquires Mobile Productivity Company Quickoffice |url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/06/05/google-acquires-mobile-productivity-company-quickoffice/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=June 5, 2012 |accessdate=March 9, 2017}} On February 6, 2013, Google announced it had acquired Channel Intelligence for $125 million. Channel Intelligence, a technology company that helps customers buy products online, is active globally in 31 different countries and works with over 850 retailers. Google will use this technology to enhance its e-commerce business.{{cite web |first=Ingrid |last=Lunden |title=Google Acquires Channel Intelligence For $125M To Boost Product Referrals And E-Commerce With Users |url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/02/06/google-acquires-channel-intelligence-to-boost-product-recommendations-and-e-commer-with-users/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=February 6, 2013 |accessdate=March 9, 2017}} The official confirmation of Google's acquisition of the Israel-based startup [[Waze]] occurred in June 2013. Waze is promoted as a "community-based traffic and navigation app".{{cite web |first=Ingrid |last=Lunden |title=Google Bought Waze For $1.1B, Giving A Social Data Boost To Its Mapping Business |url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/06/11/its-official-google-buys-waze-giving-a-social-data-boost-to-its-location-and-mapping-business/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=June 11, 2013 |accessdate=March 9, 2017}} Following the acquisition of Waze, Google submitted a "10-Q" filing with the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|Securities Exchange Commission]] (SEC) that revealed that the corporation spent $1.3 billion on acquisitions during the first half of 2013. The filing also revealed that the Waze acquisition cost Google $966 million, instead of the $1.1 billion figure that was initially presented in media sources.{{cite web |first=Rip |last=Empson |title=Yahoo And Google Are Both Spending Big Money On Acquisition Sprees And What That Says About Their Futures |url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/07/29/yahoo-and-google-are-both-spending-big-money-on-acquisition-sprees-and-what-that-says-about-their-futures/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=July 29, 2013 |accessdate=March 9, 2017}}{{cite web|title=Google and Waze seal the deal on their $1.1B purchase acquisition.|url=http://www.geektime.com/2013/06/11/mazal-tov-google-and-waze-officially-tie-the-knot/|website=Geektime|publisher=|accessdate=July 29, 2013|author=Avi Schneider|date=June 11, 2013}} The 2012 acquisition of WIMM Labs, a company that previously made an Android-powered [[smartwatch]], was confirmed in August 2013. As of August 31, 2013, Google has not publicly commented on the news concerning WIMM Labs.{{cite web |first=Natasha |last=Lomas |title=Google Confirms It Has Acquired Android Smartwatch Maker WIMM Labs |url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/08/31/google-acquires-wimm-labs/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=August 31, 2013 |accessdate=March 9, 2017}} The acquisition of Flutter, a creator of [[Gesture recognition|hand gesture recognition technology]], was confirmed by the corporation in early October 2013. The reported price is $40 million and Google spokesperson stated: "We're really impressed by the Flutter team's ability to design new technology based on cutting-edge research." Flutter's technology allows users to enact hand gestures to control navigation for apps such as iTunes, Windows Media Player, and Winamp.{{cite web|title=Google Acquires Flutter, Creator of Hand Gesture Recognition Technology|url=http://searchenginewatch.com/article/2298628/Google-Acquires-Flutter-Creator-of-Hand-Gesture-Recognition-Technology|website=Search Engine Watch|publisher=Incisive Interactive Marketing LLC|accessdate=October 8, 2013|author=Jennifer Clegg|date=October 3, 2013}} ==== 2014–2016 ==== On January 26, 2014, Google Inc. announced it had agreed to acquire [[DeepMind Technologies]], a privately held artificial intelligence company from [[London]]. DeepMind describes itself as having the ability to combine the best techniques from machine learning and systems neuroscience to build general-purpose learning algorithms. DeepMind's first commercial applications were used in simulations, e-commerce and games. As of December 2013, it was reported that DeepMind had roughly 75 employees.{{cite news|last=Chowdhry|first=Amit|title=Google To Acquire Artificial Intelligence Company DeepMind|url=http://www.forbes.com/sites/amitchowdhry/2014/01/27/google-to-acquire-artificial-intelligence-company-deepmind/|accessdate=January 27, 2014|newspaper=Forbes|date=January 27, 2014}} The technology news website [[Re/code]] reported that the company was purchased for $400 million though it was not disclosed where the information came from. A Google spokesman would not comment of the price.{{cite news|last=Helgren|first=Chris|title=Google to buy artificial intelligence company DeepMind|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/01/27/us-google-deepmind-idUSBREA0Q03220140127|accessdate=January 27, 2014|newspaper=Reuters|date=January 27, 2014}}{{cite news|last=Ribeiro|first=Jon|title=Google buys artificial intelligence company DeepMind|url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/2091500/google-acquires-artificial-intelligence-company-deepmind.html|accessdate=January 27, 2014|newspaper=PC World|date=January 27, 2014}} The purchase of DeepMind aids in Google's recent growth in the artificial intelligence and robotics community.{{cite web |first=Kwame |last=Opam |title=Google buying AI startup DeepMind for a reported $400 million |url=http://www.theverge.com/2014/1/26/5348640/google-deepmind-acquisition-robotics-ai |website=[[The Verge]] |publisher=[[Vox Media]] |date=January 26, 2014 |accessdate=March 9, 2017}} On January 29, 2014, Google announced it was selling its [[Motorola Mobility]] unit to China-based [[Lenovo]], for $2.91bn. The company kept the extensive patent collection used to develop Android products, considered the most valuable part of the original deal.{{cite news|title=Google sells Motorola Mobility to Lenovo for $2.91 billion|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/business/technology/google-sells-motorola-mobility-to-lenovo-for-291-billion/2014/01/29/92836bce-8932-11e3-833c-33098f9e5267_story.html |accessdate=January 30, 2014|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=January 30, 2014|first=Cecilia|last=Kang}} Nonetheless, the sale price was significantly less than the $12.5 billion Google had bought Motorola Mobility for. The $2.91bn price tag consisted of $660 million in cash, $750 million in Lenovo ordinary shares, and a $1.5 billion 3-year promissory note.{{cite news|title=US Moto X production plant of Motorola to be shut down by year end|url=http://www.fortworthnews.net/index.php/sid/222467207/scat/42acbe017a594c30/ht/US-Moto-X-production-plant-of-Motorola-to-be-shut-down-by-year-end|accessdate=June 1, 2014|work=Fort Worth News}} In March 2014, Google confirmed it had purchased the remnants of gaming startup, [[Green Throttle Games]], which developed a [[Bluetooth]] gaming controller for [[Android (operating system)|Android]].{{cite web|first=Devindra|last=Hardawar|website=VentureBeat|url=http://venturebeat.com/2014/03/12/google-buys-green-throttle-games-which-could-be-a-big-part-of-its-set-top-box/|title=Google buys Green Throttle Games, which could be a big part of its Android set-top box|date=March 12, 2014|accessdate=March 12, 2014}} In May 2014, Google announced it had purchased [[Quest Visual]], maker of the augmented reality translator app Word Lens.{{cite web|title=Google Acquires Quest Visual, Maker of 'Word Lens' App: Image-Based Translation Works With iOS, Android, Glass|url=http://www.latinpost.com/articles/12891/20140518/google-acquires-quest-visual-maker-of-word-lens-app-image-based-translation-works-with-ios-android-glass.htm|website=LatinPost|accessdate=May 19, 2014}} In June 2014, Google purchased satellite imaging firm [[Skybox Imaging]] for $500 million.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-27785546 |title=Google buys satellite firm Skybox Imaging for $500m|work=BBC News|date=June 10, 2014|accessdate=June 11, 2014}} In July 2014, Google purchased the online music service [[Songza]].{{cite news|url=http://www.cnet.com/news/google-buys-songza-a-pandora-like-player-where-context-is-king/ |title=Google buys Songza, a Pandora-like player where context is king|work=[[CNET]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|date=July 1, 2014|accessdate=July 1, 2014}} On September 10, 2015, Google announced to form strategic partnership with Mobvoi to bring Android Wear to mainland China.{{cite web|title = Moto 360 launching in China thanks to strategic partnership with Mobvoi|url = http://ausdroid.net/2015/09/10/moto-360-launching-china-thanks-strategic-partnership-mobvoi/|website = Ausdroid|accessdate = December 18, 2015}} In October 2015, Google invested in a China-based artificial intelligence (AI) company, Mobvoi. The funding will enable the Company to further enhance its core AI technologies, and develop new consumer products empowered by AI.{{Cite news|title = Google Invests in Chinese Search-and-Smartwatch Startup|url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/google-invests-in-chinese-search-and-smartwatch-startup-1445339005|newspaper = Wall Street Journal|access-date = December 18, 2015|issn = 0099-9660}} In July 2016, Google announced that it had purchased Moodstocks, a startup which specializes in instant [[Computer vision|image recognition]].{{cite web|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/google-buys-french-startup-moodstocks-2016-7|title=Google just bought a startup that specializes in 'instant object recognition'|last=Hartmans|first=Avery|website=Business Insider|access-date=2016-07-07}} In August 2016, Google acquired Orbitera, a startup that developed a platform for buying and selling cloud-based software, for around $100 million.{{cite web |first=Ingrid |last=Lunden |title=Google buys Orbitera, a platform for cloud marketplaces, for $100M+ |url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/08/08/google-buys-orbitera-a-platform-for-building-marketplaces-cloud-software/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=August 8, 2016 |accessdate=March 9, 2017}} In October 2016, Google announced it has acquired FameBit, a marketplace that connects video creators with marketers.{{cite web |first=Anthony |last=Ha |title=Google acquires FameBit to connect YouTube creators with marketers |url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/10/11/google-acquires-famebit-to-connect-youtube-creators-with-brands/ |website=[[TechCrunch]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=October 11, 2016 |accessdate=March 9, 2017}} Also in October 2016, Google acquired eye-tracking startup Eyefluence. Matt Brian of ''Engadget'' drew references to Google's [[Google Daydream|Daydream]] VR platform and Google's effort to create its own VR headsets that need eye-tracking sensors, and that the Eyefluence company, which specializes in turning eye movements into virtual actions, can be helpful in that process.{{cite web |first=Matt |last=Brian |title=Google buys eye-tracking startup to boost its VR hardware |url=https://www.engadget.com/2016/10/25/google-buys-eye-tracking-startup-eyefluence-vr/ |website=[[Engadget]] |publisher=[[AOL]] |date=October 25, 2016 |accessdate=October 27, 2016}} ===Google data centers=== As of 2016, Google owned and operated nine [[Google Data Centers|data centers]] across the U.S., two in Asia, and four in Europe.{{cite web |title=Data center locations |url=https://www.google.com/about/datacenters/inside/locations/index.html |website=Google Data Centers |publisher=Google |accessdate=December 8, 2016}} In 2011, the company had announced plans to build three data centers at a cost of more than $200 million in Asia ([[Singapore]], Hong Kong and [[Taiwan]]) and said they would be operational within two years.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20110928-700133.html |title=UPDATE: Google To Build Three Data Centers In Asia, Investment To Exceed $200M |date=September 28, 2011 |work=The Wall Street Journal |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928174147/http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20110928-700133.html |archivedate=September 28, 2011 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.datacenterknowledge.com/archives/2011/09/28/google-to-build-three-data-centers-in-asia/ |title=Google to Build Three Data Centers in Asia |publisher=Datacenterknowledge.com |accessdate=March 13, 2014}} In December 2013, Google announced that it had scrapped the plan to build a data center in Hong Kong.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.wsj.com/digits/2013/12/10/google-scraps-plan-to-build-hong-kong-data-center/|title=Google Scraps Plan to Build Hong Kong Data Center|author=Yun-Hee Kim|work=WSJ}} In October 2013, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' reported that the U.S. [[National Security Agency]] intercepted communications between Google's data centers, as part of a program named [[Muscular (surveillance program)|MUSCULAR]].{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-infiltrates-links-to-yahoo-google-data-centers-worldwide-snowden-documents-say/2013/10/30/e51d661e-4166-11e3-8b74-d89d714ca4dd_story.html|title=NSA infiltrates links to Yahoo, Google data centers worldwide, Snowden documents say|first1=Barton |last1=Gellman |first2=Ashkan |last2=Soltani|work=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|accessdate=November 1, 2013}}{{cite web |first1=Charlie |last1=Savage |first2=Claire Cain |last2=Miller |first3=Nicole |last3=Perlroth |title=N.S.A. Said to Tap Google and Yahoo Abroad |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/31/technology/nsa-is-mining-google-and-yahoo-abroad.html |website=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 30, 2013 |accessdate=March 9, 2017}} This wiretapping was made possible because Google did not encrypt data passed inside its own network.{{cite web |first=Sean |last=Gallagher |title=How the NSA’s MUSCULAR tapped Google’s and Yahoo’s private networks |url=https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2013/10/how-the-nsas-muscular-tapped-googles-and-yahoos-private-networks/ |website=[[Ars Technica]] |publisher=[[Condé Nast]] |date=October 31, 2013 |accessdate=March 9, 2017}} Google began encrypting data sent between data centers in 2013.{{cite web |first=Claire Cain |last=Miller |title=Angry Over U.S. Surveillance, Tech Giants Bolster Defenses |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/01/technology/angry-over-us-surveillance-tech-giants-bolster-defenses.html |website=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 31, 2013 |accessdate=March 9, 2017}} Google’s most efficient data center runs at {{convert|95|F}} using only fresh air cooling, requiring no electrically powered air conditioning; the servers run so hot that humans cannot go near them for extended periods.{{cite web|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160613112324/http://www.geek.com/chips/googles-most-efficient-data-center-runs-at-95-degrees-1478473/|archive-date=June 13, 2016|url=http://www.geek.com/chips/googles-most-efficient-data-center-runs-at-95-degrees-1478473/|title=Google’s most efficient data center runs at 95 degrees|website=geek.com|date=March 27, 2012|author=Matthew Humphries|accessdate=June 13, 2016}} An August 2011 report estimated that Google had about 900,000 servers in their data centers, based on energy usage.
